title: McDonald’s Stock Is Slipping Because Earnings and Revenue Both Disappointed
text:
Text size

McDonald’s stock is falling on Tuesday, following the fast-food giant’s downbeat third-quarter report, which missed top- and bottom-line expectations.

The back story. While plenty of fast-food stocks have jumped in 2019, McDonald’s (ticker: MCD) stock has gained about 15%, trailing the S&P 500’s nearly 20% gain year to date. Still, the company is a favorite among analysts, who like its strong underlying fundamentals, use of technology, embrace of delivery, and tests of meat-alternative products with Beyond Meat (BYND) burger patties. The shares got a boost from its previous second-quarter-earnings report over the summer.

What’s new. Early Tuesday, McDonald’s said it earned $2.11 a share, a dime below the $2.21 consensus estimate, on revenue of $5.43 billion, which was also slightly below the $5.47 billion analysts were expecting.

The company said that global same-store sales were up 5.9%, slightly ahead of expectations, including a 4.8% increase in the U.S., although analysts were looking for growth of more than 5% for domestic locations. McDonald’s also announced an 8% increase to its dividend, to $1.25 a share.

Editor's Choice

Looking ahead. It’s no doubt that the profit and sales miss was a disappointment for McDonald’s, and while the stock hasn’t kept pace with those of peers that have rallied ahead of the market, investors were still clearly hoping for a better showing. While international comparable sales have been a big driver for the stock lately, softness in the U.S. market wasn’t welcome news—and could spark worries that the sector is becoming more competitive (which can dampen results across the board).

Still, it wasn’t all bad news in the quarter. Although fixed costs did rise, in part on a higher-than-anticipated tax rate, part of that was also due to the company’s ongoing investments in technology, which should help McDonald’s in the future. International markets are still showing strength, and for company-owned stores in the U.S., margins expanded in the quarter.

However, the headline miss is grabbing most of the attention this morning and McDonald’s stock is down 3.8% to $201.90 in recent trading.
